items.title: Gum disease may quietly damage the brain, scientists warn
bullets: • Chronic oral inflammation could subtly impact the brain, especially in older adults, according to a new study
• White matter consists of bundles of nerve fibers that allow different parts of the brain to communicate
• When this tissue is damaged, it can interfere with memory, reasoning, balance and coordination

items.title: Here are the five key takeaways from the Fed meeting and Powell news conference
bullets: • The Federal Reserve meeting delivered on expectations and offered a few surprises
• Chairman Powell pushed back hard on another cut in December for which markets had been assigning about a 90% probability of happening
• Markets knew the end of QT was coming, but just weren't set on when
• The committee laid that to rest and said quantitative tightening would end after the Noveove

items.title: NPM flooded with malicious packages downloaded more than 86,000 times
bullets: • Attackers are exploiting a major weakness that has allowed them access to the NPM code repository
• The finding brings attention to an NPM practice that allows installed packages to automatically pull down and run unvetted packages from untrusted domains
• The PhantomRaven attackers exploited this weakness by including code in the 126 packages uploaded to NPM

bullets: • Four years ago, the number of people receiving food from the food pantry was about 15-20 a week

• The group is mainly people with disabilities and the elderly
• They say the past year has been tough for families with rising food costs

items.title: Humans evolved faster than any other ape
bullets: • UCL scientists found that human skulls evolved much faster than those of other apes
• By comparing 3D models of ape skulls, they showed that humans changed about twice as much as expected
• The findings suggest that both cognitive and social factors, not just intelligence, influenced our evolutionary path

items.title: Scientists reverse Alzheimer’s in mice with groundbreaking nanotech
bullets: • Scientists reverse Alzheimer’s in mice with groundbreaking nanotech approach

• This restored blood-brain barrier function and reversed memory loss
• Results point to a revolutionary new path for treating neurodegenerative diseases

• The death toll and extent of the damage are still unknown

• The ninth edition of the report, published Tuesday, found that 13 out of 20 metrics used to track the health impacts of climate change have reached unprecedented levels

items.title: Trump says US will restart nuclear weapons testing
bullets: • President Donald Trump says he has instructed the Pentagon to immediately start testing nuclear weapons
• The last US nuclear test was in 1992, before George HW Bush enacted a moratorium at the end of the Cold War
• No country, with the exception of North Korea, is confirmed to have tested nuclear weapons since the 1990s
